title: Merge pullreq 228
body:
I wanted to use the new Assert.assertEquivalent to compare BigDecimals in a sane way, and dsaff recommended I help with some merge activity that had not been done.  See discussion on this issue:

https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/95#issuecomment-1672519

So I forked KentBeck/junit, created branch merge_pullreq_228 in my repo, merged in from the repo with the changes in it, resolved conflicts, pushed my changes and generated this pull request.  The issue 95 discussion contains how I merged.  This should supercede pull request 228.

The actual conflicts were incredibly minor.  Perhaps I screwed something up, they were purely cosmetic, no code conflicts except a new test in AllTests.java.  All tests now complete in my local build (ant dist) so I presume everything's OK.

    dist:
         [java] JUnit version 4.10rc
         [java]     .........................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................I.I.......................................................................................................................................................................I.....................................................................................................
         [java] Time: 6.074
         [java] 
         [java] OK (566 tests)

The new assertEquivalent is working for me using the newly built junit4.10rc.jar.

title: Provide a way to call out to the run notifier from a rule
body: I want to be able to provide a rule that allows for dynamic skipping of tests instead of having to create a runner. I can do this but I don't have a way to notify junit that the test was skipped. If there was a way to pass the notifier to the rule then that would be fine.

title: ExternalResource should make description object available to before and after methods
body: The TestRule-based ExternalResource should make the description object available to the before and after methods.  Without the description object available, the before and after methods cannot customize behavior based what has been intercepted, thus it is effectively the same as @Before and @After (or the class-level equivalents if using @ClassRule).

title: Issue22: Adding assertNotEquals to Object, long and double
TemporaryFolder creates files in the current working directory if applying the rule fails
body: It would be better for TemporaryFolder to throw an exception if its getRoot/newFile/newFolder method is called before create() is called. Otherwise incorrect use of the rule (for example http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/23546) can pollute the current working directory with temporary files, because `new File(null, fileName)` produces a relative path.

title: Fixes #278: TemporaryFolder creates files in the current working directory if applying the rule fails

title: Change Paramaterized.java to be more extensible
body:
In this particular case, declaring methods and members private precludes extending the Parameterized runner to do 'other things' during the course of a Parameterized Test.

In my particular case, I wanted to change the names of the Tests run by the Parameterized runner to be "test_Name[i]_arg1_arg2 etc..."

Whilst I'm not asking for this naming change to JUnit itself, I cannot see any reason to stop people from extending the Parameterized test runner, and I cannot see any logical reason to mark these methods or fields as private.

I have also written a gist to show how I used my changes to create a new, extended test runner that does what I need:

https://gist.github.com/1141041

title: Allow to specify date in @Ignore
body:
I'd like to be able to ignore a failing test for a couple of days because red makes me nervous. Being what I am, I often forget to remove `@Ignore` annotations. A simple solution would be to have a date field in the annotation, say, "until".

Or maybe a new `@IgnoreUntil` annotation but that would need either a change of the core or to fix issue #116

title: Why is there an "errors.clear()" in RunAfters?
body: The `clear()` in line 29 of [RunAfters.java](https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/blob/b3789b3f879d34bbe968d5aa51d15c8856b9d102/src/main/java/org/junit/internal/runners/statements/RunAfters.java) is probably not necessary :-)

body: You may have a look at http://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails|junit|junit-dep|4.9|jar

title: Sort test methods for predictability
body:
The order of `Class.get(Declared)Methods` was never guaranteed to match source order, and apparently could always have been affected by certain conditions relating to the sequence of symbol resolution in the Sun/Oracle VM; but a VM change in JDK 7 (soon to be backported to a JDK 6 update) makes the order quite random from run to run.

This randomness has been reported to break JUnit-based tests in Eclipse, NetBeans, and Lucene sources.

While "correct" test suites/classes should pass or fail regardless of the order of test cases/methods within them, a minority unintentionally rely on the source order to pass. It is better for these to fail predictably, for easy diagnosis and fixing by developers, than to fail randomly - especially if the random failures are manifested on particular JVM versions but not on the diagnoser's JVM.

title: Fixed issue #219
body: Fixed issue #219 where Assert.assertArrayEquals(float[],float[],float) displays an error message with doubles instead of floats. I think I might have modified the release notes by accident, so let me know if there are any issues.

title: odd and unclear language in Result javadoc
body:
http://junit.sourceforge.net/javadoc/org/junit/runner/Result.html

This doc says:

   A Result collects and summarizes information from running
   multiple tests. Since tests are expected to run correctly, successful
   tests are only noted in the count of tests that ran. 

Should this be, instead, this?

   A Result collects and summarizes information from running
   multiple tests. Since tests are expected to run correctly, only successful
   tests are noted in the count of tests that ran. 

That seems to be clearer.

title: TestWatchman.failed should not be invoked for AssumptionViolatedExceptions
body:
I have set up a TestWatchman which is out of sync with the regular JUnit test reporters since the failed method is invoked even when the test passes as an assumption fails.

I believe the least astonishing thing to do here is no not invoke failed for AssumptionViolatedExceptions.
